Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, the above argument is persuasive. I feel rather strongly on my opinion that college athletes shouldn't be paid. I thought it was for the love of the sport. There was a time in this country when athletes were paid barely a living wage. When they simply played and competed because they loved what they were doing. When students agree to compete at the college level, it should be because they love their sport and want to contribute to their new school, first and foremost. If the student doesn't believe their new team is worth their time, unless they are getting paid, they will put in less effort and be less likely to form real bonds with team members.

Many athletes at the college level are also already being paid, in a sense, in terms of scholarship money. These students are receiving free educations based on their athletic talents and abilities. The reason people go to college should be to gain a better education, not as a way to make money based on athletism.

That can be taken further to being unfair to the sports that are being paid less than what they are worth. Early in high school students may focus only on bettering themselves in a sport that will pay top dollar in college, and other school sports will be neglected and not get top athletes. Competition seems to rule in this country. Paying college students to play, takes the competition out of the sports all the way from high school and on. It is a disservice to other students who don't play, and it will make students less likely to appreciate a college education or to focus on their studies.
